section.text: Hi. Good morning. John -- good morning, everybody. John, there seems to be a bit of a disconnect in, in-commercial aero and the messaging from Boeing and Airbus. So engine deliveries for Pratt and CFM were up significantly and Airbus has the OEMs, the engine OEMs are catching up, but Boeing says talks about the bottleneck, which you referred to earlier. So are you seeing more volumes for LEAP 1A versus LEAP 1B, how do we make sense of this difference that we think is occurring on the LEAP?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Robert Spingarn", "section_number": 1, "uuid": "24a7ef72-00f3-435f-936a-44af3f0b4b96", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Melius Research"}

section.text: Okay. So First of all, let me agree with you that it is confusing, I think it's confusing for everybody at the moment. But let's start off with the broad picture and then talk about Howmet before any commentary on a wider basis. So I think the big picture is commercial aerospace continues to grind higher. Everybody is trying to do the right things and airlines are improving. I think aerospace manufacturers are improving their throughputs and the engine manufacturer supporting those aircraft builds are also doing their part of the whole thing. I guess not everything is going perfectly as we've seen from some of the numbers and some of the disconnects apparent from commentary on calls last week.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "John C. Plant", "section_number": 2, "uuid": "c58f8e8d-f95a-40cb-86c0-0d3b83bec25a", "speaker_title": "Executive Chairman & Chief Executive Officer at Howmet Aerospace"}

section.text: Let me deal with Howmet first and say, we've been really well prepared through the last year and beyond, as you know, we started recruitment of labor in the second quarter of last year and hired almost 1,000 people last year. Through year-to-date, I think we're approaching now something like 1,500 people through the end of the third quarter.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "John C. Plant", "section_number": 2, "uuid": "c58f8e8d-f95a-40cb-86c0-0d3b83bec25a", "speaker_title": "Executive Chairman & Chief Executive Officer at Howmet Aerospace"}

section.text: And then I think the most salient factor for ourselves was that during September is that compared to the schedules and delivery requirements that we thought we would see for both September and the fourth quarter, we saw a complete rebasing of those requirements where we've had arrears which should be built up according to, I think the anticipated engine mills, in particular. And as we know, the anticipated engine builds were not as high as -- the actual is not as high as anticipated. And you saw Airbus commenting on the fact they had gliders in the like 70 at one point, then it's down to maybe 10 or 20. So while I'll say deliveries of engines did improve, I don't think anybody believes that the quantity of engines that was originally envisaged to be built were built.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 3, "speaker": "John C. Plant", "section_number": 2, "uuid": "c58f8e8d-f95a-40cb-86c0-0d3b83bec25a", "speaker_title": "Executive Chairman & Chief Executive Officer at Howmet Aerospace"}

section.text: In terms of the splits of whatever was delivered on LEAP between 1A, 1B, 1C, we don't have any visibility into that, I mean we do note that from the call last week, from GE Aviation which provides a lot of those engines is that they were significantly up with an improved deliveries, I think, in the near 350 engines. How many went to Airbus, how many went to Boeing, COMAC and indeed how many of those engines, which we also -- sometimes forget they go to airlines or spares and also aircraft leasing companies or spares, I don't really know, it's difficult to judge.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 4, "speaker": "John C. Plant", "section_number": 2, "uuid": "c58f8e8d-f95a-40cb-86c0-0d3b83bec25a", "speaker_title": "Executive Chairman & Chief Executive Officer at Howmet Aerospace"}

section.text: Certainly, you feel as though there was enough engines in the whole system, but maybe they were out of parts away difficult to really know. Nevertheless, the big picture is those actual builds both by CFM engines and LEAP engines were less than a bit envisaged and I think we've heard in the past about restrictions around structural castings, in particular, we probably not confined just do that.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 5, "speaker": "John C. Plant", "section_number": 2, "uuid": "c58f8e8d-f95a-40cb-86c0-0d3b83bec25a", "speaker_title": "Executive Chairman & Chief Executive Officer at Howmet Aerospace"}

section.text: And therefore, when customers looked at where they were and what they expected to finish the year with and also where they had received from ourselves, for example, all of the airfoils they required and more maybe is to balance their own inventories for the end of the year is that they were cut back. And so despite still sequential growth quarter-on-quarter that growth is not as high as we had envisaged. So right now, we've drawn our labor recruitment down significantly. So we'll be probably recruit selectively in a few areas in the fourth quarter, essentially, the rest will go to zero and though because we don't want to certainly stop production, we're going to carry about $70 million of additional inventory, which will hit our cash balance we ended the year.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 6, "speaker": "John C. Plant", "section_number": 2, "uuid": "c58f8e8d-f95a-40cb-86c0-0d3b83bec25a", "speaker_title": "Executive Chairman & Chief Executive Officer at Howmet Aerospace"}

section.text: And then, of course, we need that inventory to carry us through into the first quarter where we do expect those requirements will be placed back on us significantly, engine build will improve and hopefully, aircraft production will improve. And so we're trying to smooth ourselves out, so we'll utilize all of the labor that we recruited, carry on with production put it into inventory, so we have a smooth startup into the start of next year. So we keep all of our customers happy. But it does enable us to stop ourselves hiring a lot of people and so we'll eliminate some of that cost, albeit, as you can imagine, we were holding that cost in the month of September and we are into the balance of the year.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 7, "speaker": "John C. Plant", "section_number": 2, "uuid": "c58f8e8d-f95a-40cb-86c0-0d3b83bec25a", "speaker_title": "Executive Chairman & Chief Executive Officer at Howmet Aerospace"}

section.text: So that's the big picture. In terms of exactly what the rate of production of the 737 is and the A320, I don't think we are best placed that and I believe that most people are heading off on the sell side to Seattle this week, so you probably get a clearer picture during those visits. So I don't whether that covers it out for you, Rob, but just trying to give you a sweep through the whole situation.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 8, "speaker": "John C. Plant", "section_number": 2, "uuid": "c58f8e8d-f95a-40cb-86c0-0d3b83bec25a", "speaker_title": "Executive Chairman & Chief Executive Officer at Howmet Aerospace"}

section.text: That's really helpful, John and even with what you just said and I am heading out there with the others. Just on the 87, are you still looking for 15 chipsets for this year? And do you have any insight into next year?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Robert Spingarn", "section_number": 3, "uuid": "b251aad8-e0b8-4e11-a17a-dccc9cd1dae5", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Melius Research"}

section.text: We have a revised skyline for next year. We don't have much for this year, I think it's going to be de minimis of any production on the 87. My guess is it's probably just a one month that we've seen previously, I don't really know. It's pretty opaque to us and I'm assuming there's inventory in the system for that. We do have skylines showing clear improvements on the 787 build during the course of next year and I think from memory, it's probably the back end of the year at around about five aircraft per month.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "John C. Plant", "section_number": 4, "uuid": "0d232a17-5286-48ae-9e9b-8f88788f7e81", "speaker_title": "Executive Chairman & Chief Executive Officer at Howmet Aerospace"}

section.text: And I do have confidence that there is a market requirement for that because when I look at the return of international demand for travel, just look at, I'll say, the cutbacks that were made in widebody during the last few years, then, if anything, my guess is that there's going to be a higher demand on wide body, which will support a rate for both Airbus and for Boeing for their A350s and 787s above that rate. So I'm actually tending towards the optimistic side of fundamental demand.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "John C. Plant", "section_number": 4, "uuid": "0d232a17-5286-48ae-9e9b-8f88788f7e81", "speaker_title": "Executive Chairman & Chief Executive Officer at Howmet Aerospace"}

section.text: And then the only question that we have is, in terms of our own guidance is how conservative should we be because we do hear this noise that you refer to about exactly how many were made and where the parts are and what are the constraints. And so that also causes us to be just a little bit cautious given the factors that we've encountered in the last month or two enrolling into the end of the year, albeit against we see that spiking up in the first quarter.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 3, "speaker": "John C. Plant", "section_number": 4, "uuid": "0d232a17-5286-48ae-9e9b-8f88788f7e81", "speaker_title": "Executive Chairman & Chief Executive Officer at Howmet Aerospace"}

section.text: Thank you, John. I appreciate all the detail.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Robert Spingarn", "section_number": 5, "uuid": "3e0dcbd1-678f-4c0f-a1cb-88a9dfbe637c", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Melius Research"}

section.text: Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "John C. Plant", "section_number": 6, "uuid": "4357ef6c-dfab-44d5-b910-3f60a19db2a0", "speaker_title": "Executive Chairman & Chief Executive Officer at Howmet Aerospace"}

section.text: Good morning. Can you hear me, guys?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Gautam Khanna", "section_number": 8, "uuid": "3e8182f6-03bb-4b40-bc43-e5e9396f6520", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Cowen"}

section.text: Can hear clearly, Gautam. All good.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "John C. Plant", "section_number": 9, "uuid": "6edd7669-b561-44cb-b533-dfdef7091fd1", "speaker_title": "Executive Chairman & Chief Executive Officer at Howmet Aerospace"}

section.text: Terrific. See, I wanted to ask if you could talk about share gain opportunity. So anything incremental on titanium and are any of these pinch points on engines accruing to your benefit where customers are engaging you on casting, re-forging speak to that?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Gautam Khanna", "section_number": 10, "uuid": "07690952-d653-4a00-b7b7-34b57bf2a100", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Cowen"}

section.text: In the -- I mean, the biggest pinch points for engine is I think has been around the structural castings, there is probably some engine controllers as well, but I don't really know that it's probably lots of other things, which I'm not fully aware of. But I think the commentary around structural castings is pretty widely publicized. In the short term, it doesn't really -- it presents an opportunity to us because there is a specific tooling and certification procedures which are required and so it's really is a case of getting the structural castings from the developer supplier.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "John C. Plant", "section_number": 11, "uuid": "986aeda3-2ad5-43a5-a5fe-b4c9194f6432", "speaker_title": "Executive Chairman & Chief Executive Officer at Howmet Aerospace"}

section.text: In terms of ourselves, while we have been tighter than we'd like on structural castings is that we don't believe that we've caused any engine build issues and indeed beginning to see in that segment significant improvements in our throughput and abilities. And is not quite as good as the flow of airfoils that we've been seeing because that's been a really, I'll say, high-class output for us during the year. But short term, nothing we can point to, I think in the medium to longer term, we will see benefits on the structural casting side across the various sectors of the industry, but nothing for us to put into let's say, 2023 planning at all.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "John C. Plant", "section_number": 11, "uuid": "986aeda3-2ad5-43a5-a5fe-b4c9194f6432", "speaker_title": "Executive Chairman & Chief Executive Officer at Howmet Aerospace"}

section.text: On titanium, which was your other question, is that those orders continue to improve. So we've booked additional orders for during the third and fourth quarter and that's looking better for us. Albeit there's still significant areas to go because we still have, in particular, one of the airframe manufacturers, which has got a lot of inventory and hasn't really yet moved to cut orders lease on the supply base. So more to come on that subject as we move into next year.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 3, "speaker": "John C. Plant", "section_number": 11, "uuid": "986aeda3-2ad5-43a5-a5fe-b4c9194f6432", "speaker_title": "Executive Chairman & Chief Executive Officer at Howmet Aerospace"}

section.text: Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Gautam Khanna", "section_number": 12, "uuid": "59437a4f-bd48-4331-bda5-5fd7c3b6b1b4", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Cowen"}

section.text: Thanks. Good morning.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "David Strauss", "section_number": 14, "uuid": "0113d04d-27e8-4f12-9fba-e2dc99c23d19", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Barclays"}

section.text: Hi, David.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "John C. Plant", "section_number": 15, "uuid": "77136a02-4769-4fef-a3c8-4fa4b70a3c84", "speaker_title": "Executive Chairman & Chief Executive Officer at Howmet Aerospace"}

section.text: John, so to try to simplify this, are you at 31 a month on the MAX on the engine side or you're at 45 to 50 on the engine side for Airbus and it's just really has to do with shortage of other parts and as a result the manufacturers kind of slowed down things to get everything aligned given that they're building below the rate that you are currently producing at?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "David Strauss", "section_number": 16, "uuid": "96e5173d-ae45-4d29-a962-4f7f8e32adb5", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Barclays"}

section.text: Yeah, we've been building at rates. So we've taken the requirements from our engine customers on the airframe manufacturers and we've just been more or less in line with that, I'll say 50 plus for A320s, as an example probably with some attempted inventory full info rate build increases next year. And in the case of Boeing, we were fully planning on the 31 a month and had anticipated those according to let's say verbal communication, not any scheduled commitments, originally were planned to rise during the first quarter of 2023. As we all know that those production levels probably have not been achieved and the -- but the airframe manufacturers and certainly on the engine side. And so where we've been in line at or even, I would say, meeting for rate increases next year is that, that inventory is being taken back out of the system to bring it down to what actually has been produced and the requirements seen four years, in particular, the engine manufacturers look towards their own year-end and the inventory that they're carrying. So there's not much point in carrying say, additional airfoils when you have some of the other parts to go with the engine. It's pretty that much simple, David.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "John C. Plant", "section_number": 17, "uuid": "66358193-5229-49e1-8b3e-7c90c2211fd9", "speaker_title": "Executive Chairman & Chief Executive Officer at Howmet Aerospace"}

section.text: And John, do you see, at least from your side, where you set any constraints, whether it be hiring additional headcount, training headcount, raw material, anything do you see constraints to go up to the mid-50s to 60s Airbus is talking about on narrow-body and Boeing going up to, let's say, low 40s, do you see a constraint from your side of things?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "David Strauss", "section_number": 18, "uuid": "697238c0-880c-405e-b178-eedc42b5591b", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Barclays"}

section.text: Not from our side, we think our tight point is in structural castings have been or are being addressed, so that's in good shape. We are going to pull back on our hiring, as I said, again, selectively. So we will continue, for example, hiring and training in our structural casting plants. But at the moment, if you take our airfoils, we will just stay with the labor we had at the end of the third quarter and pause it to balance our own requirements. So far, we've been able to increase our quantity of people and it hasn't really presented a great impediment to us. Sometimes the turnover of those people has been higher than we'd like, but quantity of labor has not been an issue for us so far.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "John C. Plant", "section_number": 19, "uuid": "37a09898-5f35-4818-bcc2-94acfa5c86d8", "speaker_title": "Executive Chairman & Chief Executive Officer at Howmet Aerospace"}

section.text: Thanks very much.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "David Strauss", "section_number": 20, "uuid": "7fa2dcc0-7e6e-4ce4-a8ad-a7655b595f99", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Barclays"}

section.text: Thanks. Good morning. Looking sequentially into 4Q, it looks like you're looking for a $4 million EBITDA growth on the $40 million of sales growth. Just curious, is that lower incremental driven by something like FX or mix it sounds like labor is probably a help and raw material pass-through might be a push.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Myles Walton", "section_number": 22, "uuid": "f29e3d62-95aa-44e4-ab4b-f55fcff43122", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Wolfe"}

section.text: So can you start the first sentence again, if you wouldn't mind?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "John C. Plant", "section_number": 23, "uuid": "ffef01dd-2665-4dd6-9749-6b4f7c7b04ce", "speaker_title": "Executive Chairman & Chief Executive Officer at Howmet Aerospace"}

section.text: Yeah, sure. Thanks, John. So if I just look sequentially from 3Q to 4Q, you've got pretty minimal EBITDA growth about $4 million on the $40 million sales growth. I'm just curious to what holding you back if labor and raw materials are pass-through are the issue?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Myles Walton", "section_number": 24, "uuid": "8d51ec29-4da1-42c8-84af-fe5437ce79a2", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Wolfe"}

section.text: So let me start with commentary regarding the third quarter, first, I mean, adjusted for the material pass-through, incrementals were really strong 39%, which was above the, I'll say, the midpoint of where we talked previously you said 35% plus or minus 5%. So I think that was a really strong quarter. The reason why we are being cautious about our fourth quarter is that we're carrying that labor into the fourth quarter that we probably don't need now for that reduced level of build. And so there's a labor drag plus also the preparation of, I'll say, a lot of other production parts and facilities that could go along with that. And so that's the reason why you're not seeing the same level of incremental pull-through in the first -- I mean, in the fourth quarter. So I think you should look at that just a rebalancing of ourselves as we have drawn down that $70 million plus of engine products, which is a high-margin business for us. And so I think it's completely in line with the commentary I've given.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "John C. Plant", "section_number": 25, "uuid": "324d7e3a-643e-4ed6-858b-4634e1f62e27", "speaker_title": "Executive Chairman & Chief Executive Officer at Howmet Aerospace"}

section.text: Okay. Fair enough. And then in that 10% growth sales in 2023, do you have a flavor for what we should think about from incremental margins there?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Myles Walton", "section_number": 26, "uuid": "b2d06c56-e1b7-4e19-8302-857cfa9a7db4", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Wolfe"}

section.text: I think we'll talk more about that in the February call. I know that last year, I gave a revenue guide I thought it was important for 2022, I think the same is important. So we really understand the wider picture around the company. And having the confidence that we should be anywhere from, I would say, 10% plus or minus 8% to 12% is a statement of confidence in that we're on trajectory and we're only just debating the angle of the recovery, either which rates above the normal for aerospace, see if aerospace is normally 4% or 5%, it's more than double that rate and so it's pretty healthy. But not -- we're not ready to give any margin guidance at this point.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "John C. Plant", "section_number": 27, "uuid": "52fabc90-9560-4ee1-8b11-80e529a3b4c5", "speaker_title": "Executive Chairman & Chief Executive Officer at Howmet Aerospace"}

section.text: Okay. Fair enough. Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Myles Walton", "section_number": 28, "uuid": "58780179-8725-4fd3-80de-5038975a454b", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Wolfe"}

section.text: Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "John C. Plant", "section_number": 29, "uuid": "feb6c49a-b862-4b9d-a428-f4dc38656506", "speaker_title": "Executive Chairman & Chief Executive Officer at Howmet Aerospace"}

section.text: Hey. Thanks very much and good morning, everyone. John, I wonder the -- so the 10% growth outlook for next year if aerospace is growing 20% and that's, let's say 45% of the sales base this year, it implies really minimal growth in the rest of the portfolio. So if you could just talk about the -- what's happening in the other end markets? And then specifically, maybe help us around Forged Wheels, I mean between the currency and energy pass-throughs and aluminum pass-throughs there's a lot of ups and downs, especially in terms of the revenue numbers and the margin rate. But if we think about the baseline of EBITDA dollars there and what this quarter says about what that might be going forward, any help there would be appreciated as well?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Seth Seifman", "section_number": 31, "uuid": "b1cbf14e-c40f-4409-b322-87d636f90480", "speaker_title": "Analyst at JP Morgan"}

section.text: Okay. So in terms of the defense business and oil and gas and industrial gas turbine, I think all of those will see at this point a low single-digit growth. And my guess is that maybe oil and gas will be higher, maybe defense or below, but still expecting some growth in those. So if you plan for that and laid across with the commercial aero, then the one segment where I think we're going to see a revenue decrease will be in the Forged Wheel business for the Commercial Transportation segment. So let me try to explain what we see there.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "John C. Plant", "section_number": 32, "uuid": "3b03af8b-2d10-4082-856a-1df535d351e9", "speaker_title": "Executive Chairman & Chief Executive Officer at Howmet Aerospace"}

section.text: I mean the first thing is, of course, the headline number is affected by the price of aluminum because as aluminum has fallen during the course of this year from its peak of $4,500 a ton, including Midwest premiums or Rotterdam premiums is that it's more like probably $2,800 now. And as we rebalance the pricing because we will pass that back, then you get a couple of effects of those new prices going into effect on the 1st of January is that there is a revenue decline, which doesn't affect the EBITDA dollars and therefore there is a margin rate improvement from that.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "John C. Plant", "section_number": 32, "uuid": "3b03af8b-2d10-4082-856a-1df535d351e9", "speaker_title": "Executive Chairman & Chief Executive Officer at Howmet Aerospace"}

section.text: At the same time, let me think about what do we expect by way of volumes. We do note that the order intake, for example, for Class 8 truck was the highest it's ever been in September, I think, 53,000 plus trucks, which is really, I'd say, great number, probably inflated by the fact that many say the truck manufacturers haven't been willing to take orders for next year until they were clearer regarding the input prices of their materials. So it's difficult to separate out what's really going on, except that the fourth quarter should see solid production improve compared to where we've been and I think that will continue in the first and second quarters next year.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 3, "speaker": "John C. Plant", "section_number": 32, "uuid": "3b03af8b-2d10-4082-856a-1df535d351e9", "speaker_title": "Executive Chairman & Chief Executive Officer at Howmet Aerospace"}

section.text: And my caution at the moment is in the second half of next year when I think we'll see the effect of the higher interest rates bear on the economies, in particular in Europe, which is overlaid with energy prices. And so I think there will be a dampening of demand and it's probably around more the distribution and the trader segment of the business. And so my anticipation is that, that second half of next year will be a tougher comparison to the second half of this year. And I mean, obviously, it's only speculative at this stage, so I want to be cautious about it. But I think the correct planning assumption is solid performance through the next three quarters, then anticipate a bit of a drawdown depending on how the economy is really doing and does it go into a recession or not and then try to make the assessment.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 4, "speaker": "John C. Plant", "section_number": 32, "uuid": "3b03af8b-2d10-4082-856a-1df535d351e9", "speaker_title": "Executive Chairman & Chief Executive Officer at Howmet Aerospace"}

section.text: So the best I can do at this stage is that when I look at it, my guesstimate has been something like on a volume basis that we could be, let's say, I just give you an example of the thought at the moment is on the year, maybe 300,000 or 400,000 wheels down in volume, we will probably pull half of that back by additional penetration of aluminum versus steel and I'll say another I'll say, programs, we have to increase our share. But net, I'm thinking that a little bit of volume caution in the second half plus with the effect of the aluminum reduction, we'll produce a drawdown of revenue albeit the only effect on EBITDA will be that net drawdown of volume should it occur. And I don't think there's a reason to be optimistic and say all is great and it will continue.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 5, "speaker": "John C. Plant", "section_number": 32, "uuid": "3b03af8b-2d10-4082-856a-1df535d351e9", "speaker_title": "Executive Chairman & Chief Executive Officer at Howmet Aerospace"}

section.text: I don't think it's going to -- we are going to be affected by the emissions legislation for 2024 because there's an inability to build ahead. And so it's all down to that second half assumption of next year or so, which is just a guess on commercial wheels at this stage, nothing -- nobody knows. But the way I put it out there, it's going to be good.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 6, "speaker": "John C. Plant", "section_number": 32, "uuid": "3b03af8b-2d10-4082-856a-1df535d351e9", "speaker_title": "Executive Chairman & Chief Executive Officer at Howmet Aerospace"}

section.text: Great. That's very helpful. Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Seth Seifman", "section_number": 33, "uuid": "d9350ec6-0b1a-4987-9c58-8424843aeb61", "speaker_title": "Analyst at JP Morgan"}

section.text: If you -- so if you put that wheel thing as a down, add the other single digit in commercial, I think you can get to the guidance range of that 8% to 12%, I'll give you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "John C. Plant", "section_number": 34, "uuid": "12bc6d9e-5546-4c69-9e17-5b9f18f9cab7", "speaker_title": "Executive Chairman & Chief Executive Officer at Howmet Aerospace"}

section.text: Great.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Seth Seifman", "section_number": 35, "uuid": "48e340c9-00e8-4b1b-a53d-27e3435e2302", "speaker_title": "Analyst at JP Morgan"}

section.text: Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "John C. Plant", "section_number": 36, "uuid": "a701c33a-1b3d-4ca0-997d-75a38d8b0fca", "speaker_title": "Executive Chairman & Chief Executive Officer at Howmet Aerospace"}

section.text: Thanks. John, you've been clear that you now have the labor in place to ramp up next year. So when you think about their training, you said six months or so, how much have they pressured margins to have labor this early. And how should we think about incremental margins next year when we actually get the benefit of volume coming through?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Kristine Liwag", "section_number": 38, "uuid": "f919fd80-9e28-4b6f-a945-3e8873fcbbdd", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Morgan Stanley"}

section.text: Okay. Well, we're going to pause for the main in Q4 for recruitment, not totally, it will be two or three or four plants that will continue, but out of our complete network we are choosing to pause that at this stage until we know more and let the additional people that we've already recruited during this recovery, which is some, I'll say, 2,500 come up to rate and let that hopefully, productivity improve.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "John C. Plant", "section_number": 39, "uuid": "3cd244fd-37e4-48ed-9194-b905c4783143", "speaker_title": "Executive Chairman & Chief Executive Officer at Howmet Aerospace"}

section.text: Depending on the job, it can take anywhere from I'm going to say three months to bring in somebody into the plant and to be, I'll say, reasonably effective all the way up to two years and beyond for some skilled areas and we have to move people around to try to balance all that out.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "John C. Plant", "section_number": 39, "uuid": "3cd244fd-37e4-48ed-9194-b905c4783143", "speaker_title": "Executive Chairman & Chief Executive Officer at Howmet Aerospace"}

section.text: So I think there will be the benefit for that stabilization. How much is difficult to say at this stage and it obviously depends on the growth next year. We will commence recruitment again in larger numbers in January as we expect the build rate to increase in January. We'll go to the first quarter taking some of it out of inventory, certainly fourth quarter, but we'll continue then to restart our -- and fire up to recruit people again and so that's headcount availing. I'm not yet ready to give any commentary about margins for 2023 at this point.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 3, "speaker": "John C. Plant", "section_number": 39, "uuid": "3cd244fd-37e4-48ed-9194-b905c4783143", "speaker_title": "Executive Chairman & Chief Executive Officer at Howmet Aerospace"}

section.text: Thanks, John. And maybe following up on the inventory build, I mean the castings that the shortage in castings and forgings have been well publicized and the OEMs have been very clear that there is strong demand for aircraft out there. I guess I would have thought that we'd be in an environment of full steam ahead for demand for your product. What's causing the uncertainty? And also with the $80 million inventory headwind that you highlighted in this quarter, when does this unwind and where could peak balance be?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Kristine Liwag", "section_number": 40, "uuid": "48550919-954c-429c-bd1e-39f4dbcbd1e3", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Morgan Stanley"}

section.text: Okay. I think everybody expected continued buoyancy as we did for increases in bills. I think they are occurring. It's only a question of degree. And I said if we haven't built as many aircraft as it been thought, and there seems to be a case where that's correct, you're just going off the earnings calls last year from the airframe manufacturers. And while there's a notable and real improvement in engine build, it still is in aggregate, I think a little bit lower than people had probably planned for. And so I mean, everybody is trying really hard throughout the whole system. Airlines are doing well and improving their trying hard and getting people and bringing aircraft back into service.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "John C. Plant", "section_number": 41, "uuid": "718f13ac-c42d-4868-92a3-6a67e3102369", "speaker_title": "Executive Chairman & Chief Executive Officer at Howmet Aerospace"}

section.text: I think the engine manufacturers trying really hard. Now I think the airframe manufacturers, what is trying really hard to get up this ramp and deal with all the factors that they've had to cope with in terms of which starts with COVID and the supply shortages and freight rates and just training of labor and availability and then other, I'll say, impediments in other materials in the supply chain. So there's been a lot going on. So I think everybody is trying to do the right thing. And I think all we're talking about here for Howmet is that, where some of our parts are being brought into line with what they have cut for elsewhere and maybe just a little bit of a less ambitious plan in terms of build rates just because I mean we -- I think you can see that probably we haven't built -- or there has not been as many MAX is built or maybe as many narrow-body Airbus is built as visually envisaged. Is my guesstimate from trying to assess the information available from what's been said publicly on the earnings calls of other companies.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "John C. Plant", "section_number": 41, "uuid": "718f13ac-c42d-4868-92a3-6a67e3102369", "speaker_title": "Executive Chairman & Chief Executive Officer at Howmet Aerospace"}

section.text: Thank you for the color, John.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Kristine Liwag", "section_number": 42, "uuid": "428a4d07-ae45-4c67-abc5-64ec7f85f5f7", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Morgan Stanley"}

section.text: Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "John C. Plant", "section_number": 43, "uuid": "8c238f16-e73f-4093-b961-c8fec59100b4", "speaker_title": "Executive Chairman & Chief Executive Officer at Howmet Aerospace"}

section.text: Hi. Good morning.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Elizabeth Grenfell", "section_number": 45, "uuid": "a01ae997-5f9a-498e-9458-1a6cb47306ae", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Bank of America"}

section.text: Hi. Good morning.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "John C. Plant", "section_number": 46, "uuid": "4d27f228-42e0-4b26-a6a1-2f526312e57c", "speaker_title": "Executive Chairman & Chief Executive Officer at Howmet Aerospace"}

section.text: How are the different customers prioritized in your queue, are more profitable customers prioritized first? And then -- I'll start with that.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Elizabeth Grenfell", "section_number": 47, "uuid": "2efce36f-eb4b-4ea5-a8a5-23df89e463a2", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Bank of America"}

section.text: Okay. No, we treat every customer, their requirements with equal respect. So there's no prioritization. I don't think that would be appropriate, you're either a customer and we make a commitment and when we do that, we deliver to you to the very best of our abilities.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "John C. Plant", "section_number": 48, "uuid": "95859130-7330-47ff-ba1d-3493537a6f1a", "speaker_title": "Executive Chairman & Chief Executive Officer at Howmet Aerospace"}

section.text: Okay. So if you had a certain number to ship out and the demand was mismatched, there would be no prioritization in terms of who got what?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Elizabeth Grenfell", "section_number": 49, "uuid": "be71f5fa-1bfc-44c4-8ea9-7c8bb8665483", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Bank of America"}

section.text: No, I don't think so, I think we should again respect there's a requirement our customers have placed on us. I don't think that we have a policy nor a plan nor even the ability. So if you think about our shipping docs, they operate to the MRP schedule, the customer demand and they ship. They don't say, I'll stick a few extra boxes of parts to some because they're more profitable. The people who do that, they don't have that information. So no, we supply to that which we've committed and with no instruction to say, please send to this customer because they're more profitable now.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "John C. Plant", "section_number": 50, "uuid": "dbf2da32-0779-4089-ab24-d5f4f694f794", "speaker_title": "Executive Chairman & Chief Executive Officer at Howmet Aerospace"}

section.text: Okay. Thank you very much.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Elizabeth Grenfell", "section_number": 51, "uuid": "028dc821-2e59-47a4-a79d-adecd5aa31ca", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Bank of America"}

section.text: Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "John C. Plant", "section_number": 52, "uuid": "b4e66e9d-a3e5-4396-ba3c-e69871891137", "speaker_title": "Executive Chairman & Chief Executive Officer at Howmet Aerospace"}

section.text: Hi. Good morning, everybody.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Noah Poponak", "section_number": 54, "uuid": "bc8177a9-b6b6-4faf-af07-53b4c81add8a", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Goldman Sachs"}

section.text: Hey, Noah.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "John C. Plant", "section_number": 55, "uuid": "9146daf7-0405-456b-9d57-49e48b5fac05", "speaker_title": "Executive Chairman & Chief Executive Officer at Howmet Aerospace"}

section.text: John, could you maybe just give us a broader update on where your market share gain efforts stand? It seems like that's maybe happening in part related to these supply chain challenges across the engine supply chain and then also titanium sourcing. And I know you've talked about sort of being in different RFP processes and trying to write long-term contracts? And I'm curious how that's going.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Noah Poponak", "section_number": 56, "uuid": "f1744fbe-20c0-4a14-8e1d-6c1726ae3cb6", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Goldman Sachs"}

section.text: Yeah, so as a more general note, we go through our own planning routines during the course of the year and we try to run through in terms of review each of our customers and where those opportunities may lie. And then we have our planning round where we look at -- so where is the best place to place resources, both engineering and then capital deployment. And with a view that our job as a set of executives is to basically grow above the market rate. And in my view is that if we only grow at market rates, then we're not adding the value that we should be because we should be seeking to do more than that and more than that just not in terms of margin performance, but in particular the opportunity to grow our share or take content into Howmet.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "John C. Plant", "section_number": 57, "uuid": "853b43a0-e719-42d2-9ba8-8febf73f4255", "speaker_title": "Executive Chairman & Chief Executive Officer at Howmet Aerospace"}

section.text: So that's the basic stance that we have, Noah. And then once we've got that on the see before us, all of the opportunities, then at that point, we can make our own resource decisions whether we allocate more capital to this area or that area according to the prospect of returns for it. And clearly, at that point, then we resource allocate. So it isn't a matter of just bottoms up, we just -- there's a process where everybody wants more capital or more resources, everybody gets a fair shake on it. It's not that at all, it's more. These are all the opportunities and then our job as the leadership of the company is to then determine how we allocate.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "John C. Plant", "section_number": 57, "uuid": "853b43a0-e719-42d2-9ba8-8febf73f4255", "speaker_title": "Executive Chairman & Chief Executive Officer at Howmet Aerospace"}

section.text: So whereas on the last question from Elizabeth, she was asking, do we prioritize in the short-term and the immediacy of deliveries, no, we don't, but in the long-term, absolutely, we do. So we do resource allocate to those different areas and have a clear process for doing so. And with the objective of meeting the target to be above the rate of normal increase for those end markets we serve.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 3, "speaker": "John C. Plant", "section_number": 57, "uuid": "853b43a0-e719-42d2-9ba8-8febf73f4255", "speaker_title": "Executive Chairman & Chief Executive Officer at Howmet Aerospace"}

section.text: Okay. And last quarter, I think you specified adding $20 million of revenue to the fourth quarter, fairly specifically related to titanium sourcing. Any update on that specifically and how that looks beyond this year?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Noah Poponak", "section_number": 58, "uuid": "6ea9e59c-9394-42af-8254-96a2ad603ba4", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Goldman Sachs"}

section.text: It clearly continues to improve. We've booked more orders in the end in the third quarter into the fourth quarter and that continues to be a positive for us. But it's still continuing and we have one major manufacturer where we've engaged, but still yet to really move in terms of any significant orders essentially because there's a lot of inventory of titanium in the system at the moment with that reduced wide-body build what we talked about. So more to come. I'm hopeful that we'll give you some improved assessment in February, but at the moment, if we just -- just assume that we are on track to achieve that $20 million or slightly better for the fourth quarter and it will continue to improve in 2023 and 2024.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "John C. Plant", "section_number": 59, "uuid": "8c5f8873-9f09-4df6-866c-7055767c0d18", "speaker_title": "Executive Chairman & Chief Executive Officer at Howmet Aerospace"}

section.text: Okay. Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Noah Poponak", "section_number": 60, "uuid": "e4f2a211-c770-4bc8-8f5e-0b4269baa785", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Goldman Sachs"}

section.text: Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "John C. Plant", "section_number": 61, "uuid": "3404383f-edce-46b1-9f78-8d36727f571d", "speaker_title": "Executive Chairman & Chief Executive Officer at Howmet Aerospace"}

section.text: Yeah. Hey, good morning. Thanks for the question. Could you touch on the defense decline in the quarter and specifically I guess the F-35, some of the inventory corrections you saw how much longer does that still have to go on?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Matt Akers", "section_number": 63, "uuid": "1dfac4f4-b298-4c4a-8466-9050a1ae2f0b", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Wells Fargo"}

section.text: Yeah, so our assumption is that Lockheed do produce somewhere in that $1.45 to $1.55 range this year and if anything, probably let's say just take the $150 million or a little bit less is probably the that our assumption, which will be an increase on the production in last year. And we do note that the order intake for F-35 seems particularly strong and so that 150 plus rates should continue, we think probably for the rest of the decade and so that's all good news.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "John C. Plant", "section_number": 64, "uuid": "ed0c56c0-85cc-476c-9c61-c7c13d2b7715", "speaker_title": "Executive Chairman & Chief Executive Officer at Howmet Aerospace"}

section.text: For us specifically, because for the last two years of 2020 and 2021, we did produce at a higher rate for the customer sort of schedule requirements anticipating as they did, I think they would make closer to the 150 aircraft. And as we know they produced probably in that 130 to 140 range and therefore, they carry the inventory into this year, which we said we would correct for the most part during 2022. So in particular, for the airframe and bulkheads part of the aircraft is that we've seen that downdraft and we've commented on that affecting our structures business and Ken called it out again in Q3 as the major factor on the impact on defense sales that continued the inventory correction.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "John C. Plant", "section_number": 64, "uuid": "ed0c56c0-85cc-476c-9c61-c7c13d2b7715", "speaker_title": "Executive Chairman & Chief Executive Officer at Howmet Aerospace"}

section.text: Our view is that, that will continue in Q4 and into Q1 next year and we're hopeful that by the second half of next year, the latest is that we are in balance. And so our production will be coming up on the F-35 to match rate, which will obviously be a significant improvement for us and if that's combined with the increase in rates for the 787, then we should see some very positive demand requirements for our structures business in particular and that's also part of my expectation within that range of guidance given to you for 2023?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 3, "speaker": "John C. Plant", "section_number": 64, "uuid": "ed0c56c0-85cc-476c-9c61-c7c13d2b7715", "speaker_title": "Executive Chairman & Chief Executive Officer at Howmet Aerospace"}

section.text: Thanks. That's helpful. And then if I could do one more on pension. I guess, I know you mentioned with a higher rate, but the liability, it's a little bit better, but I guess when you factor in asset returns year-to-date, is it meaningfully different kind of next year versus 2022?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Matt Akers", "section_number": 65, "uuid": "e8a73cd9-0d74-4e0f-9561-68c475fa271f", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Wells Fargo"}

section.text: Yeah, I'll pass that across to Ken to give you a little bit more color on that. But essentially, as interest rates have moved up, then that provides a downdraft on the liability side significance. Asset returns this year are lighter and lower than last year and I don't have the exact numbers to hand, that will be a negative for that situation. And then when you put two together is that along with the cash contributions we have made, we have a net liability reduction. And my anticipation is that we'll show further reduction of liability in the fourth quarter to make a meaningful change in the reduction of those legacy liabilities. And I think on a net basis, we're probably down to I mean, I guess, around $700 million-ish plus or minus, so it's a pretty diminish number for the company now, very different than it was two or three years ago.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "John C. Plant", "section_number": 66, "uuid": "5489c822-c2da-4986-a37f-e9e14346b8ef", "speaker_title": "Executive Chairman & Chief Executive Officer at Howmet Aerospace"}

section.text: But let me pass you across to Ken to comment specifically on the expected liabilities and assets.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "John C. Plant", "section_number": 66, "uuid": "5489c822-c2da-4986-a37f-e9e14346b8ef", "speaker_title": "Executive Chairman & Chief Executive Officer at Howmet Aerospace"}

section.text: Yeah, so Matt, we've been doing a lot of work on the pension and OPEB program. So if you compare to where we are today, we've improved around $85 million in terms of net liability. A lot of that's driven by actions we started taking to clip off gross liabilities going back to Q2 of 2020 believe it or not, when we took out some U.K. buyout programs. But from Q2 of 2020 to current, we've taken off about $600 million of actions, right? So that's helping drive the net liability down.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ken Giacobbe", "section_number": 67, "uuid": "898c54be-8b10-4ea1-9daa-46aedec99bae", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President & Chief Financial Officer at Howmet Aerospace"}

section.text: But as John mentioned, at the end of the year, we'll snap the line again in terms of where we're at. We get a nice favorability around discount rates because discount rates have moved from around 2.7% at the end of last year to mid 5% right now. So you're going to get a nice good guy on the liability side. To your point, the assets, if you even just track the S&P 500, they will be negative. You pushed the two of them together, though, you're going to get a nice reduction in terms of net liability. Also we've got to get to the end of the year, but we anticipate cash contributions next year will probably be the same, if not less, based on all the work that we've done over the years.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Ken Giacobbe", "section_number": 67, "uuid": "898c54be-8b10-4ea1-9daa-46aedec99bae", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President & Chief Financial Officer at Howmet Aerospace"}

section.text: Very helpful.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Matt Akers", "section_number": 68, "uuid": "b5d2e0ce-77a9-4a4c-bcb5-6f042dc2f16e", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Wells Fargo"}

section.text: Maybe I'll just add to give you a bit of a broader perspective. So when I think about the environment we're in where interest rates are going up rapidly and it's possible this week we'll see a further 75 basis points increase in federal funds rate, I mean that generally is bad news for most companies. In the case of ourselves on a net basis is that if I look at our debt then essentially all of our debt is fixed rate. And so it only can impact the refinancing of an exchange of bonds depending on what we've paid down of those bonds as well.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "John C. Plant", "section_number": 69, "uuid": "1b59bd36-5aa7-4694-b6b8-d2087d59b8e0", "speaker_title": "Executive Chairman & Chief Executive Officer at Howmet Aerospace"}

section.text: So I'm not anticipating that our interest rate costs go up at all in the next two or three years, so that's good. Our pension liabilities will go down and that's good. And when I think about the markets we serve, I think we've already had our recession in the time of 2020, 2021 and the effects of COVID and then overlay that with the specific issues that Boeing had regarding production of C-737 and 787. And so we should be set for maybe uniquely as a sector set for growth for the next two or three years and that growth should come through and our balance sheet should improve as a result of the interest rate movement. So it's a pretty unique and good set of circumstances, that's my optimism coming through. Sorry, carry on.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "John C. Plant", "section_number": 69, "uuid": "1b59bd36-5aa7-4694-b6b8-d2087d59b8e0", "speaker_title": "Executive Chairman & Chief Executive Officer at Howmet Aerospace"}

title: Q&A for HWM (Howmet Aerospace) on 10/31/22 10:00 AM ET
